posts.title: Ep. 83 "A Light at the End of the Tunnel" | Library Stories
posts.text: When her father was deported, Briana found her life turned upside down. After becoming a mentor at the Washington Heights Library, she found a new purpose and the energy to keep pushing forward.

posts.title: Ep. 83 "You're Not Alone Anymore" | Library Stories
posts.text: The Library is open to all, including a patron who had financial difficulties and needed a place to get back on his feet.

posts.title: Ep. 82 "You Go For It" | Library Stories
posts.text: Where does a person start if she is an immigrant in need of English and has recently lost her eyesight? Why, The New York Public Library, of course.

posts.title: Ep. 81 "The No.1 Source" | Library Stories
posts.text: Free early childhood programs at Harlem Library attracted Fabiola and her daughter, who loves story time and the activity workshop that lets her get messy and play with other children.

posts.title: Ep. 80 "I Am Going To Excel" | Library Stories
posts.text: It's easy for Amy to get help with her homework—and learn new computer skills—at Westchester Square Library, thanks to the Innovation Labs program.

posts.title: Ep. 79 "When I Started Reading" | Library Stories
posts.text: Summer reading—game on! Learn how trips to the nearby NYPL branch one summer changed a middle school student's life for the better.

posts.title: Ep. 78 "Coming Into Her Own" | Library Stories
posts.text: Thanks to a special partnership with a nearby school, Huguenot Park Library enables select students to exercise job skills in a welcoming, educational environment.

posts.title: Ep. 77 "I Wouldn't Be Who I Am Without That Library" | Library Stories
posts.text: "Hello Dolly" star Bette Midler describes researching her character at the New York Library for the Performing Arts.

posts.title: Ep. 76 "It's Helpful in a Big, Big Way" | Library Stories
posts.text: The Library helps to close the digital gap by lending free Wi-Fi HotSpots, and Geneal's family was lucky enough to borrow one.

posts.title: Ep. 75 "I Might Not Ever Get a Shot Again" | Library Stories
posts.text: Find out how one immigrant helps others learn to read and is going to college, with a boost from The New York Public Library.

posts.title: Ep. 74 "A Bastion of Fact and Truth" | Library Stories
posts.text: A journalist and author who won the Library's Bernstein award talks about the importance of supporting fact and evidence.

posts.title: Ep. 73 "I Want To Read Now" | Library Stories
posts.text: Experience Carol's stellar new achievement: the power to read.

posts.title: Ep. 72 "A Key Role To Play" | Library Stories
posts.text: Cullman Center Fellow and past Bernstein Book Award winner George Packer considers the role of journalists in society today.

posts.title: Ep. 71 "I Can Vote, I Can Participate" | Library Stories
posts.text: Pleased with their new English language skills and U.S. citizenship, Zahra and Hassan express their gratitude to NYPL for teaching crucial lessons as they became Americans.

posts.title: Ep. 70 "I'll Forever Be Grateful" | Library Stories
posts.text: Adriana started as a English-language student and volunteer at The New York Public Library. Now she manages outreach services to immigrants for NYPL.

posts.title: Ep. 69 "Communicating Helped Me" | Library Stories
posts.text: A middle school student finds a way to conquer math, shyness, and blog-post writing after school at Westchester Square Library.

posts.title: Ep. 68 "The Perfect Way to Master A New Skill" | Library Stories
posts.text: A graphic designer raises his game through a TechConnect course in 3D printing.

posts.title: Ep. 67 "I Don't Want To Miss a Moment" | Library Stories
posts.text: A working dad makes time to visit his infant daughter at the nearby NYPL branch in Midtown Manhattan.

posts.title: Ep. 66 "I Realized My Love for Learning" | Library Stories
posts.text: Inimfon Udoh discovered her love of learning while hitting the books at Eastchester Library in the Bronx. Now, as the first doctor in her family, Ini is back in the borough she calls home, serving the community she says inspires her.

posts.title: Ep. 65 "This Is My Contribution" | Library Stories
posts.text: Try your hand at research at the Schwarzman Building at 42nd Street, and be amazed at what you can learn—about your own family. Just ask Jennifer Maston, who took a course on African-American genealogy and came away with more than she expected.

posts.title: Ep. 64 "Making a Connection"  | Library Stories
posts.text: The New York Public Library helps homebound patrons stay connected to literature and to the world. Eastchester Library Manager Joan Aikens describes how she fulfills requests for some of her Books by Mail patrons, each with specific tastes and preferences.

posts.title: Ep. 63 "The Library Card Is Like a Passport"  | Library Stories
posts.text: Meet Jinglu, a super user of the NYPL who funnels many of her selections through a tiny branch library on Roosevelt Island.

posts.title: Ep. 62 "When I Look at the City" | Library Stories
posts.text: St. Agnes Library in Manhattan allows a range of artists to hang their work on the walls, a month at a time. This work is by a nearby artist who gets inspired by, and paints images of, vibrant New York City streetscapes.

posts.title: Ep. 61 "Something the Neighborhood Really Wants" | Library Stories
posts.text: Check out one of Manhattan's silent oases, a library space devoted to total quiet. Volunteer Roberto-Cristoforo describes how he came to monitor the room and garden at 67th Street Library.

posts.title: Ep. 60 "We're Both Gonna Fly Kites Today" | Library Stories
posts.text: There's an exciting installation at Hudson Park Library, in the children's room. Check out what happens when you put kites, scarves, or parachutes into the wind tunnel, as Jen Casado and her sons do.

posts.title: Ep. 59 "The Library Is a Place Kids Feel Safe" | Library Stories
posts.text: A library can be a safe place to work after school, but it's also important to get there safely. As a crossing guard outside Castle Hill Library, Casilda sees her role as an extension of its protective space. She knows the branch well, having grown up in the neighborhood and now takes her own daughter there.

posts.title: Ep. 58 "Too Good To Be True" | Library Stories
posts.text: When Pelham Bay Library patron Patrick Mulligan came upon some comic books for sale, he bought them for his own children. But his wife pointed out that the books bore the NYPL imprint, so he knew he had to act.

posts.title: Ep. 57 "I Enjoy Every Minute Here" | Library Stories
posts.text: Story time is about so much more than just stories, says JC, who has found learning at 58th Street Library "changed everything" for her baby. There, they enjoy books, parenting tips, and even sign language as a way to build skills for life long learning. "Even though I was a teacher," JC says. "I still need to learn how to be a mother."

posts.title: Ep. 56 "The King of the Library" | Library Stories
posts.text: In the early 20th century, philanthropist Andrew Carnegie donated $5.2 million to build more than 60 libraries throughout New York City. For many years, the Carnegie libraries were heated by coal, and each had a custodian who lived inside the branch, often with family, to keep the building warm. Raymond Clark, custodian for three decades, lived at NYPL's Washington Heights Library with his son Ronald and granddaughter Jamilah. Now, their former apartment has been renovated and will serve as a teen center. We invited Ronald and Jamilah back to Washington Heights to see the renovation and

posts.title: Ep. 55 "It's Important To Build Literacy" | Library Stories
posts.text: Not every mom designs a curriculum for her preschool child, but NYPL helped Trenicia see possibilities—especially when she added more than one branch library into the equation. The combination of multiple library locations, diverse children's programs, and lots of books helped Trenicia boost her daughter's early literacy and ability to engage with different people.

posts.title: Ep. 54 "Going in the Right Direction" | Library Stories
posts.text: Relationships are a big part of reason that NYPL's BridgeUp after-school program works for Matthew. When he gets to the Bronx Library Center, he gets a snack, checks in with his mentors and friends, does homework, and gets to spend time on personal projects, including his electric skateboard. He says the program has a "great positive vibe" and is motivating him to greater academic success.

posts.title: Ep. 53 "An Act of Citizenship" | Library Stories
posts.text: When artist and author Melinda Hunt started to research the potter's field on Hart Island, she turned to The New York Public Library for newspaper articles tracing its story. Today, as founder of the Hart Island Project, she shares her findings in public places, including nearby City Island Library, to help people learn about Hart Island's unique spot in New York City history.

posts.title: Ep. 52 "A Better Experience of the World" | Library Stories
posts.text: Sometimes, it takes a little help to raise your game. Jeremy has worked with his NYPL tutors after school for two years. With more confidence and knowledge, he enjoys doing his homework, and his school has recognized him as most improved. Now Jeremy is thinking big: going to college and getting a job.

posts.title: Ep. 51 "This Is a Place for Growth" | Library Stories
posts.text: When vocal artist Russell Saint John was preparing for a concert of the music of greats Paul Robeson and Hall Johnson, he turned to his nearby Hamilton Grange Library to conduct his research. "To have all of this information at your fingertips is phenomenal," he says. "This is a place for growth, and that's what The New York Public Library is for me."

posts.title: Ep. 50 "People Forget These Kids Have Dreams" | Library Stories
posts.text: Inspired by a librarian at the Grand Concourse Library, actress Youmie Francois decided to create a program for area school-age children. Now she's providing lessons in acting, dance, music, and more, and has created a scholarship named after the librarian who encouraged her. "People didn't know that this library had all the stuff that it had, all the opportunities that it provides," she says.

posts.title: Ep. 49 "I Really Want To Help People" | Library Stories
posts.text: Who better to coach young readers than an enthusiastic high school student with some training? That's the idea behind NYPL's Literacy Leaders, and Zippy captures the spirit well in her regular reading group with Henry and Manuel at the Mosholu Library. One of the Library's many free programs, Literacy Leaders develops career skills for Zippy and her peers while helping young readers see where books can take them.

posts.title: Ep. 48 "I Can Do It" | Library Stories
posts.text: Overcoming a fear of technology wasn't on the course description. But NYPL's Office Readiness Series gave James more than basic computer skills training when he was ready to look for a job. Although the classes were free, James says he considers them "extremely valuable."

posts.title: Ep. 47 "The Library is a Safe Haven" | Library Stories
posts.text: Working in the New York City public schools, Terri created a partnership with Aguilar Library to let 8th graders sample library careers. But it wasn't just to provide job skills. Terri thinks libraries offer a complementary learning space to that inside schools, and says that's important because many kids don't have adequate structure at home.

posts.title: Ep. 46 "Reading Is the Greatest Thing in the World" | Library Stories
posts.text: Getting free help with homework can make a big difference in a child's life.

posts.title: Ep. 45 "It's Almost Like a Temple" | Library Stories
posts.text: Fiber artist, designer, and cultural activist Xenobia Bailey has a favorite institution where she goes for inspiration: the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture.

posts.title: Ep. 44 "The After-School Program Is Really Fun" | Library Stories
Ep. 43 "I Really Love the Library" | Library Stories
posts.text: It's no fun feeling disoriented in school, Yuridia recalls, so she was thrilled to get extra help from a free tutor at the Port Richmond Library to understand and finish her homework.

posts.title: Ep. 42 "A Deeper Story" | Library Stories
posts.text: Behind every great book lies a deeper story. This week, NYPL Board Member Gordon Davis tells the story of his parents, Allison Davis and Elizabeth Stubbs Davis, and how they came to research and write "Deep South," a seminal anthropological study of racism in the American south in the 1930's.

posts.title: Ep. 41 "This Is Definitely My Good Luck Charm" | Library Stories
posts.text: Salesman Paul Couvertier figured he might need a half hour to prepare a resume when he stopped in one day at Aguilar Library. However, by the time he was finished, he had spent two hours getting all the forms together for his application.

posts.title: Ep. 40 "I Am Her Most Important Teacher" | Library Stories
posts.text: When Alina Baez became a mother, she signed up for the Family Literacy Workshop at the Bronx Library Center and started discovering tips for building a strong platform for language and learning.

posts.title: Ep. 39 "Working Together for the Common Good" | Library Stories
posts.text: As he prepares for the release of his documentary on The Green Books, Calvin hopes to share with current and future generations the impact that a small group of people can have when they come together to create a resource for the common good.

posts.title: Ep. 38 "It's Not Just For Kids" | Library Stories
posts.text: For hip hop dancer Maria Fraguas Jover, researching at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts is a transformative experience.

posts.title: Ep. 37 "I Got the Idea" | Library Stories
posts.text: With the help of NYPL’s StartUp competition and the resources at the Science, Industry & Business Library, Steve founded Quikicks, a line of hands-free footwear that allows the user to step in and out of their shoes with ease.

posts.title: Ep. 36 "The Best Place for My Baby" | Library Stories
posts.text: Khadijah Haman loves the Library for all the resources it offers for her baby. As the mother of a young child, she has observed the gap between educational opportunities for the rich and the poor—and how the Library helps bridge that gap.

posts.title: Ep. 35 "They Offered Me the Job" | Library Stories
posts.text: When Alyona Glushchenkova first came to the US, she had limited English skills and no one to help her with the transition — until she discovered the Library’s range of free ESOL and career classes.

posts.title: Ep. 34 "I Just Like What I Do" | Library Stories
posts.text: Mercury Rodriguez, a custodian at NYPL’s Kingsbridge Library, loves his job.

posts.title: Ep. 33 "A Little Glimpse Behind the Scenes" | Library Stories
posts.text: Ben West, founder and director of UnsungMusicalsCo., is on a mission to give new life to the lesser-known authors and works of American musical theater.

posts.title: Ep. 32 "English Will Change My Future" | Library Stories
posts.text: As a student in NYPL’s free ESOL classes, Raul Flores is proud to say that he has gone from knowing just a few basic English phrases, to being able to converse comfortably with other English speakers.

posts.title: Ep. 31 "I Thought It Was Amazing" | Library Stories
posts.text: With the help of the Library’s free TechConnect classes, Mary Ellen learned the skills necessary to take her school’s website to the next level.

posts.title: Ep. 30 "Trying to Reach the Next Generation" | Library Stories
posts.text: Myles Dawson, a Junior Scholar at NYPL’s Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, has a dream: to change the world through comic books.

posts.title: Ep. 29 "My Friend Said, 'Go to the Library'" | Library Stories
posts.text: After coming to the United States in 2014, Yerfi Saldana found that his limited English skills were holding him back, both professionally and personally.

posts.title: Ep. 28 "I Have Always Loved to Answer Questions" | Library Stories
posts.text: As a member of the team at AskNYPL, Matthew fields research questions both big and small from curious people all over the globe — questions that even the internet cannot answer.

posts.title: Ep. 27 "I Get to Do Something With My Life" | Library Stories
posts.text: Learn about how Tahmin is using technology to impact her community, and the sense of pride and purpose it brings her, in this week’s Library Story.

posts.title: Ep. 26 "It Has Enriched My Life" | Library Stories
posts.text: During her songwriting process, Sara comes to the Library to discover the rich histories and traditions that have shaped folk music around the world.

posts.title: Ep. 25 "A Wonderful Curiosity About People" | Library Stories
posts.text: As a personal financial counselor for the Library’s Money Matters program, Steve Poppel encounters people from all walks of life.

posts.title: Ep. 24 "I Would Like My Children to Speak English" | Library Stories
posts.text: Juan Cordero immigrated to the United States from the Dominican Republic in order to build a better life for himself and his family. When one of his children gave him a flyer about free English classes at the Library, it opened up a whole new world of opportunities.

posts.title: Ep. 23 "Websites Are My Works of Art" | Library Stories
posts.text: When web designer Belinda Crichlow wanted to take her coding skills to the next level, she joined NYPL’s free Project Code program. Her experience has made her more confident, brave, and ready to take on the digital world.

posts.title: Ep. 22 "Anywhere in the World in a Book" | Library Stories
posts.text: When Angelo Pecunia’s granddaughter Bianca was just one year old, he brought her to the Great Kills Library and let her pick out as many books as she wanted.

posts.title: Ep. 21 "Fulfilling My Own Destiny" | Library Stories
posts.text: As an immigrant who successfully climbed her way to the top of the corporate ladder, Lucy Chan is using her retirement as an opportunity to help younger immigrant women navigate their new lives in the city.

posts.title: Ep. 20 "Those Endless Possibilities" | Library Stories
posts.text: As a dancer for the New York City Ballet and a self-described "nerd" for ballet history, Silas has made the dance collection at LPA an integral part of his life and career.

posts.title: Ep. 19 "Fish! Fish! Fish!" | Library Stories
posts.text: Enoch Park loves animals, and when he wanted to learn how to set up his new aquarium he knew just where to go.

posts.title: Ep. 18 "Life as It Should Be" | Library Stories
posts.text: As he dove into his research at the iconic Stephen A. Schwarzman building, Álvaro was deeply moved by the incredible magic of the building and resources that surrounded him.

posts.title: Ep. 17 "I Was Driven" | Library Stories
posts.text: Family historian Julia Bruno has lost both of her parents in the past five years. Looking for ways to process her grief and connect with her Italian ancestry, Julia turned to the St. George Library Center on Staten Island.

posts.title: Ep. 16 "We Want Them To Feel Cared About" | Library Stories
posts.text: Mona Gambardella leads her own group of knitters and crocheters at Mariners Harbor Library, where they have made over 150 scarves for the homeless so far.

posts.title: Ep. 14 "I Touched That Book" | Library Stories
Ep. 13 "I Love My Job" | Library Stories
posts.text: Javier Velez is a the floor manager at BookOps, where materials from The New York Public Library and The Brooklyn Public Library are sorted on a giant laser scanning book sorts. He tells his Library story and the sense of pride he feels training the other workers on the floor, knowing that he’s preparing them with skills that will last a lifetime.

posts.title: Ep. 12 "I'm Living My Dream" | Library Stories
posts.text: For our next several episodes of Library Stories we’re sharing interviews from BookOps, the distribution center for The New York Public Library and Brooklyn Public Library. The employees here are passionate about getting materials to our users on time and in great condition.

posts.title: Ep. 11 "Phoenix" | Library Stories
posts.text: Juan Nolasco's Library Story is one of rising from the ashes. He became homeless after the death of his mother, but the staff and resources at the 125th Street Library were there to help him pick himself up and become the artist he is today.

posts.title: Ep. 10 "Nobody Writes Stories About Apartments" | Library Stories
posts.text: This week, children's book author Johanna Hurwitz shares her love of books, the importance of writing what you know, and the joy she gets from knowing her books are in libraries.

posts.title: Ep. 9 "Turn a Negative Into a Positive" | Library Stories
posts.text: This week's story comes from Christine Richards, who like so many people, lost her job in the great recession. But after she stumbled she knew where to go, and has been visiting the Parkchester Library regularly to make use of its space, computers and resources. She was able to turn a negative into a positive and find a new job through her own determination and the library she used a home base during a tough time.

posts.title: Ep. 8 "Uniquely Empowering" | Library Stories
posts.text: Chancey Fleet’s Library Story began as girl when she visited the Andrew Heiskell Talking Book Library for the first time. She tells about that first experience, and how it lead her to want to teach other visually impaired people to use technology to communicate.

posts.title: Ep. 7 "Serious Readers" | Library Stories
posts.text: Dorothy Carey used Jefferson Market Library often when she and her husband were raising their two daughters in the West Village. Years later, after her husband passed away, she returned to the Library and found a group of like-minded people to help her in this new phase of life.

posts.title: Ep. 6 "All You Need In Life" | Library Stories
posts.text: Bigelow Society Member Nancy Wight shares her Library Story and why she's giving back to the New York Public Library. As a teacher of English as a Second Language, she always brought her students to the Library to get them a library card. Today, she still believes in the power of the Library so much she’s included it in her estate plan, in memory of her daughter.

posts.title: Ep. 5 "Big Family" | Library Stories
posts.text: Dianna Owens has a big family. She and her husband bring their six children to the Mott Haven Library all the time, partly for the classes, programs, books, and resources, but also because of the welcoming community they’ve found there.

posts.title: Ep. 4 "My Introduction to the World" | Library Stories
posts.text: After being laid off from her job in the hospitality industry, Yvette Carpenter knew she had to learn some new computer skills if she was going to compete in the job market. She used The New York Public Library’s TechConnect classes to learn Excel, Word and redo her resume – all for free. She was able to secure a new job, and perhaps more importantly built the skills to reintroduce herself to the world.

posts.title: Ep. 3 "A Job for the Summer" | Library Stories
posts.text: Evan Chesler is the Chairman of the Board of The New York Public Library, but his Library Story started long before he assumed that role. When he encountered an obstacle that nearly destroyed his dream of going to law school, he used hard work and the Library to push himself forward.

posts.title: Ep. 2 "We'll Make It Work" | Library Stories
posts.text: John Tomlinson started a small gay men’s book club out of his apartment, but as it started to grow he realized there was a real demand and began looking for a new space. When he approached Frank Collerius of the Jefferson Market Library about possibly hosting the growing group, Frank accepted without hesitation, simply saying “we’ll make it work.”

posts.title: Ep. 1 "Born to Be a Librarian" | Library Stories
posts.text: Dawn Collins (Zimmerer) has always wanted to be a librarian. After a long career in retail, finally she gained the confidence follow her dream and went back to school to get her master’s degree in Library Science. Today, she’s a librarian at the West Farms branch and has never loved her job more.
